reviewText: It's a pet peeve of mine and maybe a few others share it: Re-enactors. The documentary footage, the still photographs and, of course, the men interviewed make this very compelling. But throughout the narrative the producers spliced in endless footage of modern-day re-enactors. The sense of viewing the past is broken every time they did it and they did it a lot. Why do I want to watch some modern-day young guy dressed up it WWI kit and playing at war? I was very disappointed when I saw The History Channel had a hand in making this it became obvious, because the History Channel does exactly the same thing. That's why I never watch The History Channel. There is no shortage of film and still photography from the Great War. There was no reason to do this except someone must think if it isn't in color the audience will switch it off. That's nonsense, of course. I would gladly have given this five stars if they had just thrown all the re-enactor footage in the trash. So, bottom line: It's worth watching, absolutely. But they added elements that weren't needed. That drooped it down to three stars for me. Pity.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I really could not give it 5 stars because basically this is only the British view point of  "The Great War". It was interesting to listen to the comments by a few of the survivors of the war but i really believe "First World War the complete story" is a better choice only because it covers not only Britain's view point also how the war started and the view points of all of the other main countries involved including the U.S. toward the very end.It's also important to listen to all sides of any conflict before drawing any conclusions and  as i said this is only the British view.
summary: The better choice for me was "First World War-the complete story".

reviewText: I only gave it 4 stars (I would like to give it 4 1/2) because there were no subtitles, and I am a little hard of hearing. Otherwise I would have given this 5 stars for sure. This was a very interesting series of programs. I have read several books on the pilots who flew during WWI, but this was the first time I had heard stories from the men in the trenches. My brother-in-law teaches history and wants to borrow it for his class. The things these people had to endure...it's amazing anyone survived.  And it's pretty amazing that most of the people interviewed lived to be 100 or more years old!

reviewText: I am enamored with WWI. This is an excellent video for both novice and WWI expert. The sound and picture quality are a little below what a lot of people would consider acceptable, but I love black & white videos and the grainy quality gives it more of a realistic quality to me. Information is accurate and detailed.

reviewText: I wasnt expecting much for the price i paid for this documentary..and have watched other WW1 documentaries 4-6 times the price as i paid for this one. I was surprised how good it was..it was very interesting footage and stories told by actual soldiers in WW1..(most around 100 years old)..that gave a real feel for what it was like to be in this war..and what it was like.Great footage also.

reviewText: Only the British would have had the foresight of interviewing these men before they left us.  Honest truth about their lives in the trenches, their thoughts on the war then and at the end of their lives. Not only a lesson on war, but real hitory from the real source. Narration is perfect for setting up the interviewee comments. 1914 to 1918 covered, different viewpoints revealed... a must have for any real WW1 history buff. Miss these guys and I never met them.
summary: The Last Voices of WWI - A Generation Lost (DVD)

Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a very well produced and valuable program that honors and preserves the history and sacrifice of British soldiers during World War One. Veterans, some well into 100+ years of age, were interviewed over a 15 year period.  Harry Patch aged 111 and Henry Allingham aged 113 are featured as well as the Battles of the Somme, Arras and Ypres.  The RFC/RNAS/RAF is nicely represented! The program has six episodes, slightly less than 4 hours of interviews, archival film footage and reenactments that complement the story.  I particulary enjoyed watching and listening to how the veterans related their stories. This program is a must have for anyone with an interest in World War One!  Other DVD programs that I recommend areThe First World War - The Complete SeriesThe Complete Story: World War IandWorld War I:  The Great War.

reviewText: I see that this DVD set has been reduced to a blowout price - six bucks.  There is something both eloquent and appalling in that, as we approach the 100th anniversary of the start of `the war to end all wars.'  The BBC taped these interviews in the late 90s, in anticipation of the 90th anniversary of Armistice Day (November 11, 1918).  Time was running out for the survivors of the Great War -  infantry soldiers (volunteers and conscripts), officers, sailors, pilots, nurses, medics, armament factory workers, wives and family members.  Those interviewed are 'old parties' - in their late 90s, verging on 100.  All died before final edit and release of the program.  While there are a few London aristocrats, most speak with the broad accents of the north country.  Before the war, they led modest lives: insurance clerk, shoe repairman, farm laborer or simply unemployed.  For many, military service was an escape from a dead-end existence.Their voices are the substance of the program; they are heard not just for the last time but the first time, as well.  These men and women had held their awful memories and crushing losses in stoic silence, for a lifetime.  It never occurred to them that they might have a chance to say something or that anyone would be interested; without exception, they speak clearly and honestly.  There's no point in giving a chapter-by-chapter guide; get the program.  I should note that it can also be listened to, from start to finish, without a single visual image.  This can be used as a follow-up, for a second or even third take.  Throughout 2 discs and 6 chapters (3 hours), there is an over-arching theme: the journey - both national and personal - from self-confidence to mute terror to disillusionment and finally hopelessness and desperation.A few samples -'People said Haig was wrong in making us go and fight the enemy.  Dammit, we couldn't sit there forever.  We had to get on with the job.''Up to then, the whole thing had been most enjoyable but now my heart stood still.  I suddenly realized this was warfare and I might not return.''We stood on the deck and sang:Homeland, homeland, when shall I see you again?Land of my birth, fairest place on earth, I'm leaving you.Oh it may be for years, it may be forever.Homeland, homeland.''The men that won the war was only the Tommy who was always cheerful, who always got a story to tell, the chap who carries on.''I didn't want to go...  I lived a sheltered life, I suppose.  And army life didn't appeal to me at all.  I had no inclination to fight anybody.  I mean, why should I go out and kill somebody I never knew?  For what reason?  There's no reason for it at all, in my way of thinking.''I picked them off, one by one.  I don't know how many I killed but it must have been in 3 figures because I was a very good shot.  I had very good eyesight, very good indeed.""Being taken prisoner was the worst thing that I could ever imagine happening to me.  It made me feel as if I was a coward.  I was letting my country down, I was letting my battalion down, I was letting my family down - and it was a horrible, horrible feeling.''All hell let loose.  I'd never been under shellfire before and I was very nearly sick with fright, sick with fright.  For the first time I realized that I may die and I'd never experienced anything like it before - and I was terrified, I was shaking.''Oh, no - we didn't think it was in vain -  but I wouldn't volunteer to do it again.  We thought it was going to be a lovely little game, you know?  But it wasn't - it was wicked, wicked.''Why have we lost millions of men -  and the Germans, too - and all the other people that was in the war?  Why have we done that and then they settled it around a damned table?  Why couldn't they do that at first -  and save all those lives?''Like me, you get stuck by yourself, you know?  Things go through your mind, really.  Well, why did I join?  I still think -  it was for no bloody purpose.''I was happy.  I knew I did something for my country.'Unfortunately, Amazon no longer allows links to other sources.  I'll just refer readers to the Telegraph's series 'Inside the First World War' for added info.
summary: An essential document of the 20th century -

reviewText: These are historical interviews along with very old WWI footage. I highly recommend them for those interested in the "war to end all wars", but they tend to drag a bit in places due to the usual heavy-handed style of our friends across the pond. While sometimes scholarly, the can also drone on. Still, they represent an invaluable historical record of a war now nearing its centennial anniversary.

summary: The Last Voices of WWI-A Generation Lost

reviewText: A study of World War I  must precede any study of World War II.  This unique documentary provides a picture of what these young soldiers endured.  The sound of their voices, at ages nearing 100, is incredibly good;  I had no difficulty with their enunciation.  The six segments are logically organized.  This incredibly moving film must not be missed by anyone interested in 20th century history.
